plein, -e, _adj._ full, open (air, field, door, etc.); en --, in the middle or midst of, completely, all; en pleine figure, right in the face; en -- décembre, in the middle of December; à pleins cheveux, right by the hair; à pleine bouche, with mouth wide open, lapping up without using the hands.
pleurer, _v._ to weep, weep for; -- à chaudes larmes, to shed hot tears.
pli, _m._ fold, bend, plait, depression, hollow, elevation.

plume, _f._ feather, pen; -- à l'oreille, pen over the ear.
plus, _adv._ more, in addition, some more, plus, no more; le --, most; -- ...

--, no longer, never more; non --, either; de --, in addition, more; de -- en --, more and more; de -- ou de moins, more or less (when = "sldquo;some more" or "pldquo;plus" or when emphatic, _s_ is pronounced).
poêle, _m._ stove; _f._ frying-pan (_oê_ in this and in the next word is pronounced as _oi_ in poil).

and s._ mischievous, naughty, broad (of a joke), scamp.

pouiller, _v._ to get the lice out of, clean, get into.
poule, _f._ hen, fowl, chicken; chair de --, goose-flesh.

prévenance, _f._ consideration, obligingness, kind attention, kindness.

propos, _m._ purpose, object, remark, talk; à -- de, in regard to.
proposer, _v._ to propose; se -- de, think of, intend to.
propre, _adj._ proper, clean, own; -- à rien, good for nothing; c'est du --, that's (he's) a pretty mess.
propriétaire, _m., f._ proprietor, proprietress, owner, landowner.
pro-recteur, _m._ vice-rector (acting head of a German university, the head being the reigning prince).
Prosper-César, Prosper Cresar (the French usually hyphenate two given names).
Provence, _f._ Provence (the extreme southeastern province in France before the Revolution); rue de --, Parisian street a little north of the Boulevard des Italiens.
puce, _f._ flea; secouer les puces, to shake the fleas from, beat.
puiser, _v._ to draw, draw forth, dip.
pyrosis, _m._ pyrosis (burning pain in the epigastrium; final _s_ pronounced).
qualité, _f._ quality, rank, capacity; en sa -- d'étourdi, by virtue of his giddiness or frivolity.
quart, _m._ quarter; moins le --, a quarter to.

quasiment, _adv._ almost, as it were, a sort of.
quatre, _card._ four; -- à --, four (steps, etc.) at a time.

and adv._ that, in order that, than, as, whether, why, how, but (after a negative), let, see that (used also to avoid repetition of a conjunction, then takes the meaning of the first conjunction); ne ...
--, only, but, except, what; c'est --, introductory phrase, often better left untranslated, sometimes = it is because, that is, but.

pr._ whom, which, what, ever; ce --, what, etc.; ce -- c'est -- de, that is what it is to; je ne sais --, some or other; qu'est-ce -- (c'est --) cela?, what is that?; ce -- de, how much; ce -- c'est que d'habiter, what a life one leads in.
or int.)_ what, which, of what kind, who; -- qu'il soit, whoever he may be.
que, however; -- chose de brun, something dark.
quérir, _v._ to look for, fetch (used only in infinitive after aller, venir and envoyer).

pr._ who, which, what, whoever; ce --, who, which, what, etc.; -- ...
quitte, _adj._ quit, quits, free; il n'aurait pas été si facilement -- avec, he would not have got off so easily with.
quitter, _v._ to quit, leave, lay aside, take off, let go; ne pas -- des yeux, not to take the eyes off.

pr._ what, which; de --, wherewith, means, the wherewithal; -- que, whatever; je ne sais -- (de), I don't know what, something; à -- bon?, what is the good of it?; -- qu'il en soit (de), whatever may be, however it may be; sur --, whereupon; -- que ce soit, anything whatsoever; comme --, how.
R rabattre, _v._ to put down, pull down, lower.
raconter, _v._ to tell, tell of, relate, recount.

ramasser, _v._ to pick up, gather; ramassé, -e, _adj._ thick-set, heavy.
rame, _f._ oar; à toutes rames, rowing at full speed.
Rameau (Jean Phillippe), French composer and musical theorist (1683-1764).

ranger, _v._ to range, arrange, draw up, put in order; se --, draw up, draw aside; rangé, -e, steady, settled.
ranimer, _v._ to reanimate, revive; se --, brighten up, be revived.
rappeler, _v._ to recall, remind; se --, remember, recall.
rapport, _m._ report, relation; -- à, on account of.
rapporter, _v._ to bring back or in, report; s'en -- à, leave the matter to.
rapprocher, _v._ to draw or bring near; se -- de, approach again, draw near, be reconciled with.
ras, -e, _adj._ closely cut, short-napped; au -- de, on a level with (_s_ not pronounced).

rassurer, _v._ to reassure; se --, reassure oneself, be reassured.
Ratier, proper name, _cf._ ratier, -ère, _adj._ rat-catching (of a dog, etc.), whimsical.
rattacher, _v._ to tie again, attach, make one cling to; se --, be attached.
ravager, _v._ to ravage (with dissipation, etc.), lay waste, ruin.
rayon, _m._ ray, beam; -- de miel, honeycomb.
rebondir, _v._ to rebound, jump back or again.
réchapper, _v._ to escape again, escape; nous en sommes réchappés, we have had a narrow escape.
réchauffer, _v._ to heat again, warm up, warm.
rechercher, _v._ to search for again, seek again, search for, seek.
recommandation, _f._ recommendation; lettre de --, letter of introduction.
reconduire, _v._ to reconduct, lead back, take back.

recteur, _m._ rector, priest (used in latter sense in Brittany).

redemander, _v._ to ask again, request the return of.
redescendre, _v._ to descend again, go down again.

réduit, _m._ retreat, nook, small room (in garret, etc.).

réflexion, _f._ rcflection; faire une --, to reflect; toute -- faite, after thinking about it carefully.
reflux, _m._ ebb, ebbing tide (_x_ not pronounced).
refuser, _v._ to refuse; se --, to refuse, deny oneself; s'y --, refuse to do it.
regagner, _v._ to regain, go or get back to, win back.
regaloper, _v._ to gallop again, trot around again (colloquial, derived from galoper).
regarder, _v._ to look at, look, regard, watch, concern, look out (for).
rehausser, _v._ to heighten, enhance, set off.
rein, _m._ kidney, back; autour des reins, around the waist; les reins courbés, with back bent.
rejoindre, _v._ to rejoin, meet, join; se --, meet.
réjouir, _v._ to rejoice, cheer, delight; réjoui, -e, delighted, beaming.
relevé, _m._ course immediately following the soup.
relever, _v._ to lift again, raise, lift, turn back; se --, raise oneself, rise again, stand up, get up again, rise.

remettre, _v._ to put back, put on again, put again, deliver, give, give over, recover; se --, put oneself back, give oneself over, place oneself again, recover one's composure, make up; se -- à, begin again; se -- avec, get back into the good graces of, "mldquo;make up with." remonter, _v._ to remount, go or come up again, go back, go up, get in again.
remplir, _v._ to fill, fulfil; rempli, -e, filled, full.
remporter, _v._ to carry off or back.
remuer, _v._ to move, stir; se --, bestir oneself, stir, move about, move; remuant, -e, stirring, busy.
rencontre, _f._ meeting; à sa --, to meet him.

rendre, _v._ to render, give back, make, restore, depict; se --, make or render oneself, surrender, betake oneself, go; rendu,-e, rendered, knocked up, done for, "aldquo;all in." renfermer, _v._ to shut up again, enclose, contain.
renfler, _v._ to swell; renflé, -e, swollen, bulging.
renfoncer, _v._ to plunge deeper, settle down.
renouveler, _v._ to renew, repeat; -- l'air, ventilate; se --, be renewed.
renseignement, _m._ information (also in _pl._); prendre des renseignements, to make inquiries.
renseigner, _v._ to inform; se--, get information.
rente, _f._ income, annuity, income from government bonds or stocks, etc.
rentrer, _v._ to reënter, go back in, come in, return.
renverse (à la), _adv._ backward, on one's back.
renverser, _v._ to overturn, upset, throw over or back.
renvoyer, _v._ to send back or away, dismiss, reflect.
repaître, _v._ to feed; se -- de (avec), delight in.
répandre, _v._ to scatter, spread; se --, spread, be spread, be spread out, scatter, launch, burst.

repartir, _v._ to set out again, start again, leave.
repasser, _v._ to pass again, repass, pass on, iron, strop, sharpen.
repentir (se), _v._ to repent; repentant, -e, repentant, penitent; repentir, m.
replier, _v._ to fold again, fold, fall back; se --, fall back, retreat.
répondre, _v._ to respond, answer, reply; -- de, answer for, assure of.
reporter, _v._ to carry or bring back.
reposer, _v._ to repose, rest; se --, rest.
repousser, _v._ to push back, repulse; repoussant, -e, adj.
reprendre, _v._ to take again, get again, take on again, take up, take to, continue, catch again, take back, regain, reply, resume.
représenter, _v._ to represent, give; se --, represent oneself, picture to oneself, imagine.
reprise, _f._ retaking, darn; à plusieurs reprises, several times.
reproduire, _v._ to reproduce; se --, be reproduced.
requin, _m._ shark (applied also to a predatory or voracious person).
réserver, _v._ to reserve; se -- de, reserve the right to.
résoudre, _v._ to resolve, solve; résolu, -e, resolved, resolute.
resplendir, _v._ to be resplendent; resplendissant, -e, resplendent.
ressaisir, _v._ to seize or take hold of again (in this word and in all the words to and including ressouvenir _re_ is pronounced as in retenir).
ressentir, _v._ to feel again, feel, experience.
ressortir, _v._ to go or corne out again, stand out (in contrast).
reste, _m._ rest, remains, trace; du (de) --, au --, for the rest, besides; ils ne sont pas beaux de reste, they are not any too good.
rester, _v._ to remain, stay, stand; -- là, remain there or unchanged.
rétablir, _v._ to reëstablish; le silence s'était rétabli, it had become silent again.
retaper, _v._ to make over or up.
retenir, _v._ to retain, hold back, hold, keep, restrain.

Rethel, town in northeastern France (department of Ardennes); it was captured in 1650 under Louis XIV, also by the duke de Guise in 1611 (minority of Louis XIII, not under Henri IV as stated by de Maupassant).
retirer, _v._ to retire, draw back, take off or from, get, draw out; se --, retire, withdraw.
retomber, _v._ to fall again, fall back, relapse.

retourner, _v._ to go back, return, turn around, turn over again or inside out, turn over, turn; se --, turn around or over; s'en --, return, go back; voir de quoi il retourne, to see how the land lies, get at the truth.
retracer, _v._ to retrace, sketch, lay out.
retraite, _f._ retreat, retirement, tattoo; battre en --, to beat a retreat.
rétribuer, _v._ to remunerate, give a salary to.
retrouver, _v._ to find again; se --, find oneself again, be found again, meet again.
réunir, _v._ to reunite, bring together, collect; se --, meet.
réveillon, _m._ midnight feast, supper (on Christmas Eve, etc.).
revenir, _v._ to come back; return, recover, be due; -- sur ses pas, retrace one's steps; revenu à lui, having recovered his self-possession, having become himself again.
revers, _m._ reverse, facing (of cloth), back stroke (from left to right), back.
revêtir, _v._ to reclothe, put on, cover.
revivre, _v._ to revive, come to life again, live again.
revoir, _v._ to see again; au --, good-by (till next meeting).
rez-de-chaussée, _m._ ground floor (first syllable is pronounced _ré_).
riboter, _v._ to go on a spree.
--, nothing; -- que, only, merely; -- de bon, nothing good; -- de temps, no time; ça ne fait --, that makes no difference; -- autre chose que, nothing but.
rigoler, _v._ to be very much amused, split one's sides (familiar).
rigueur, _f._ rigor; tenir -- à, to treat coldly, refuse to come to.
rire, _v._ to laugh; donner à -- à, make laugh; _m._ laughter, laugh; -- à, smile upon; -- aux éclats, burst out laughing.
roc, _m._ rock (mass of rock still in the earth).
rôle, _m._ rôle, part; à tour de --, in turn.
roman, -e, _adj._ Romance (belonging to the Latin languages).
rompre, _v._ to break, rupture, rend; se --, be broken, break.
and m._ round; -- de cuir, round leather cushion.
ronflement, _m._ snoring, snore, humming, roar, roaring, whir.
ronger, _v._ to gnaw, eat away or out.
roquefort, _m._ roquefort cheese (made in Roquefort in south-western France, department of Landes).
and m._ red, red-hot, redness, blush, rouge.
rouiller, _v._ to rust; se --, get rusty.
roulement, _m._ rolling, rumbling, beating (of a drum).
rouler, _v._ to roll, roll up or about, turn on or over, turn; se --, roll oneself, roll about; -- sur, roll on, deal with.
Roumanille (Joseph), Provençal writer and poet, one of the founders of the brotherhood known as les Félibres consisting at first of seven modern Provençal poets including Mistral (1818-1891).
route, _f._ route, way, highway, road; en --, on the way.
royal, -e, _adj._ royal; Place Royale, square in eastern section of Paris, now called Place des Vosges, before the French Revolution it was a center of fashion.
rude, _adj._ rude, rough; -- partie, great game.
ruer, _v._ to throw, cast; se --, throw oneself, rush, dash.
Saâdi, Sadi, celebrated Persian poet, _see_ also Gulistan (c.
sabir, _m._ mixture of Arabic, French, Spanish and Italian spoken in the Levant, jargon.
saigner, _v._ to bleed; -- du nez, have the nosebleed.
and s._ saintly, holy, sacred, saint.
Saint-Christophe, Saint Christopher (name of a church and street in Heidelberg).
Saint-Cloud, town on the Seine, a western suburb of Paris.
Saint-Nazaire, city and port at the mouth of the Loire.
sainte-nitouche, _f._ sanctimonious person, one who affects an innocent air.
Saint-Paul (hôtel), former residence of Charles V in the Saint-Antoine quarter of Paris.
Saint-Pierre (île de), island in the Swiss Lake of Bienne (Rousseau tried to take refuge here in 1765).
Saint-Vincent, name of a footbridge over the Saône in Lyons.
saison, _f._ season; marchand des quatre saisons, costermonger, huckster.
salle, _f._ hall, room, office; -- de police, guard-room; -- à manger, dining-room; -- de jeu, gambling-room.
saluer, _v._ to bow to, bow, greet, salute.
sans, _prep._ without, except for, had it not been for; -- que, _conj._ without.
Saône, _f._ Saône (river flowing into the Rhone at Lyons; _a_ not pronounced).
sapas, _m._ a slang word, translate: greedy-gut.
and s._ Saracenic, Saracen (written Sarrasin when _s._).
sauter, _v._ to jump, leap, skip, leap over, pop, be broken (bank); -- sur les sabres, leap to draw the sabers; -- au cou de, fall on the neck of.
sautoir, _m._ Saint Andrew's cross; en --, cross-wise, across the shoulders.
sauver, _v._ to save; se --, save oneself, run away.
Savenay, village in the department of Loire-Inférieure.

savoir, _v._ to know, know how, know to be, find out, can; -- gré à, thank; on ne sait comment, somehow or other; je ne sais quel, I do not know what, some; je ne sais plus quel, I have forgotten what; est-ce que je sais?, do I know, "aldquo;and a lot of other things," etc.
and s._ wicked, heinous, villain, wretch, rascal.
scellé, _m._ seal; mettre les scellés, to geal up (the possessions of a debtor).
schako, _m._ shako (military cap resembling a truncated cone and having a plume or pompon, now little used in the French army).
sculpter, _v._ to sculpture, carve, engrave (_p_ not pronounced).
pr._ himself, herself, itself, themselves, etc.
and s._ dry, dried up, skinny, keen, sharp, curt, harsh, dried up fellow.
sécheresse, _f._ dryness, harshness, lack of feeling.
secourable, _adj._ helpful; -- pour, willing to help.
secours, _m._ succor, aid, help, assistance; au --!, help!
séculaire, _adj._ secular, a hundred years old, venerable.
séduire, _v._ to seduce, attract, lead astray, be attractive; séduisant, -e, seductive, attractive.
seigneur, _m._ lord; le Seigneur, the Lord.
sélam, _m._ Oriental name for a bouquet of flowers expressing a thought (of love); derived from Arabic salam, salutation (_m_ pronounced).
selon, _prep._ according to; -- que, according as.
Seltz, Seltzer (town in Hesse); eau de --, Seltzer-water.
semaison, _f._ seed-time, natural sowing of seeds by the plants themselves (obsolescent).
semblable, _adj._ similar, like, of this kind.
semelle, _f._ sole (shoe); battre la --, to tramp.
sens, _m._ sense, direction (final s not pronounced).
sentir, _v._ to feel, perceive, smell, smell of; se --, feel oneself, feel that one has or is, feel; -- à plein nez, fill the nose with odors of, reek with.
séparer, _v._ to separate; se --, be separated, separate.

serrer, _v._ to tighten, squeeze, press, clench, grip, keep, fit tight on, draw tight, shake (hands); se -- le coeur, be or make heart-sick; serré, -e, tight, close, compact, dense, pressed; avoir le coeur serré, be heavy-hearted.
service, _m._ service, commission; pour votre --, to serve you; faire le -- de, run to.
servir, _v._ to serve, be of use; se -- de, make use of, use; -- de, serve as; pour vous --, at your service.
and adv._ if, to see if, whether, what if, so, yes (contradiction), you ask if; -- ça se peut, the idea of asking whether that's possible.
pr._ (usually with le), his, hers, its, his own, etc.; les siens, his people or family, etc.
signaler, _v._ to signal, call to one's attention.
signe, _m._ sign; faire --, to make a sign, beckon.
silence, _m._ silence; garder le --, to keep silent.
silhouette, _f._ silhouette (drawing representing a profile traced by means of a shadow), outline.
simple, _adj._ simple, mere, only; -- soldat, private.
simuler, _v._ to feign, simulate, take on the appearance of.
singe, _m._ monkey, ape (applied to a disagreeable person, = "bldquo;bear").
siphoïde, _adj._ in the form of a siphon, siphonal.
sitôt, _adv._ so soon, as soon as; -- que, _conj._ as soon as.
six, _card._ six; tous les --, all six (_x_ pronounced as _s_).
Skouliani, Skuleni (town on the Russo-Rumanian frontier).
soin, _m._ care, attention; _pl._ care, attentions, aid.
soir, _m._ evening; le --, the evening, in the evening; hier au --, yesterday evening.
soit, _adv._ be it so, so be it, whether; -- que ...
Soldatenthal, town in the former French department of Meurthe.
solliciteur, -euse, _m., f._ solicitor, solicitress, one who asks assistance.
somnoler, _v._ to be overcome with sleep, drowse.
songer, _v._ to dream, muse; think; mais songez, but just think.
sonner, _v._ to ring, ring out or for, strike.
sonnette, _f._ small tell; coup de --, ring; donner un coup de --, to ring.
sort, _m._ lot, fate; le -- en est jeté, the die is cast.
sorte, _f._ sort, kind; en quelque --, in some way, in a way; en -- que, _conj._ so that.
sortie, _f._ going out, exit, egress, release, departure.
sortir, _v._ to go out, come out, get out, stick out, put or take or be out, leave, project, graduate.
sottise, _f._ foolishness, foolish act or remark, stupidity; avoir la -- de, to be foolish enough to.
sou, _m._ sou, cent; gros --, two cent piece; cent sous, five francs, dollar (familiar); une pièce de vingt sous, a franc.
soucier, _v._ to disturb; se --, care, be concerned.
souffler, _v._ to blow, blow out or up, breathe, puff.
souhait, _m._ wish; à --, as one would wish.
soulever, _v._ to raise, lift; se --, raise oneself, rise.
soumettre, _v._ to submit, subject; soumis, -e, _adj._ submissive.
souper, _v._ to take supper, eat supper; _m._ supper.
sous, _prep._ under, beneath, in; -- votre respect, save your respect.
sous-préfecture, _f._ sub-prefecture (house, function, district, etc., of a sub-prefect).
soutenir, _v._ to sustain, bear, maintain, support, keep up.
and m._ subterranean, subterranean passage, tunnel.
souvenir (se), _v._ to remember; il vous en souvient, you remember it; _m._ memory, recollection, remembrance, souvenir.
Spandau, city and fortress near Berlin.
spectacle, _m._ spectacle, show, play, display, sight.
staroste, _m._ starost (Polish nobleman, or in Russia = bailiff, head of a commune).
or f._ steppe (great treeless tract in Russia and Siberia).
stéréotyper, _v._ to stereotype; stéréotypé, _m._ stereotyped character.
sucre, _m._ sugar; -- en poudre, powdered sugar.
sucrer, _v._ to sugar, sweeten; sucré, -e, _adj._ sweet.
suffire, _v._ to suffice, be enough; suffisant, -e, sufficient.
suiffeux, _m._ fat and greasy fellow (slang, derived from suif); gros -- à ne rien faire, big fat good-for-nothing.
and adj._ Switzerland, Swiss (written suisse when _adj._).
suite, _f._ following, retinue, succession, result, rest; tout de --, immediately; par --, in consequence; par -- de, because of; à la -- (de), after, behind; de --, in succession.
sur, _prep._ on, upon, over, near, about, toward, to; prendre --, to take from; -- -le-champ, at once, on the spot; sauter -- ses pieds, to leap to his feet; rouler -- l'or, roll in money.
surnuméraire, _m._ supernumerary, one not yet receiving a salary.
surplis, _m._ surplice (outer white garment of the clergy).
surplus, _m._ surplus; au --, moreover, besides, however.
surprendre, _v._ to surprise, take by surprise.
sursaut, _m._ start, shock; en --, with a start.
surveillant, -e, _m., f._ watcher, watchman, guard, guardian.
survenir, _v._ to come on or up unexpectedly.
taffetas, _m._ taffeta (formerly a heavy silk, now a thin, glossy silk; _s_ not pronounced).
tailler, _v._ to cut, cut out, carve; at faro: to hold the cards and play alone against all, deal.
taire, _v._ to suppress, keep quiet; se --, be or become silent, keep quiet.
talonner, _v._ to be close on the heels of.
talus, _m._ embankment, bank, slope (_s_ not pronounced).
tant, _adv._ so much, so many; -- que, conj.
so long as, as much as, so much, as many; -- bien que mal, as well as possible, fairly well.
tantôt, _adv._ soon, a little ago, before long, just now; -- ...
and s._ roistering, noisy, uproarious, riotous, brawler, roisterer, noisy fellow.
taper, _v._ to slap, strike, stamp; -- de l'oeil, drop off (asleep).
tapis, _m._ carpet, rug, table-cover, cloth; -- vert, green baize (of the table).
tarabuca, _f._ used by Gautier as the name of an Arab air, probably erroneously derived from darabukke (Arahic), a kind of tambourine or hand-drum.
Tarascon, town on the Rhone, north of Arles.
Tarbes, town in the department of Hautes-Pyrénées.
tarder, _v._ to be late, be slow in, be long in; il lui tardait de, he was anxious to.
tarir, _v._ to dry up, exhaust; ne point -- en, never get tired making.
pr._ (familiar), you, to you (occasionally: thee, to thee).
Te Deum, _m._ Te Deum (a hymn sung as a service of thanksgiving; pronounced as in Latin).
tel, -le, _adj._ such; un --, such a, such and such a one, so and so; connu pour --, known as such, known to be so.
tellement, _adv._ so, to such a degree.
temps, _m._ time, weather; dans le --, in former times; dans les premiers --, at first (pronounced as the adverb tant).
tendre, _v._ to stretch, stretch out, extend, band, bang, drape; -- l'oreille, listen intently.

tenir, _v._ to hold, keep, get, keep to, stick to, be contained in; tiens!, tenez!, wait!, see!, there!, here!, ah!; -- à, insist on, be attached to, cling to, cherish, be anxious about, deliver (a speech) to; -- dans, hold in, be contained in; il n'y tint plus, he could not stand it any longer; se --, remain, keep, stand, be; je ne (me) tiens plus sur mes jambes, I cannot stand up any longer; faire -- à, have sent to.
tenue, _f._ bearing, carriage, dress, full dress, form, formality; en grande --, in full dress; -- de soirée, evening clothes.
terminer, _v._ to termina to, end, finish; se --, end, etc.
terrain, _m._ soil, piece of land, ground.
terrasse, _f._ terrace, flat roof of an Oriental house.
terre, _f._ earth, land, cultivated land, ground, earthenware; par --, on the ground or floor; à --, to the ground or floor.
and m._ terrible, terrible side of thing.
tête, _f._ head, top, expression; en --, at the head, in front; -- de lettre, letter-head; tenir -- à, to resist, oppose.
téter, _v._ to suck; donner à --, nurse.
Thèbes, Thebes (reference in the text is to the celebrated ancient Egyptian city, not to the Greek village).
ti, dialectic particle used in questions: je sais- --?, do I know?
timbre, _m._ bell, hand-bell, tone, sound, stamp.
timbré, -e, _adj._ stamped; papier --, officially stamped paper (with the revenue stamp).
tirade, _f._ tirade (long speech in a drama).
tirer, _v._ to draw, pull, draw lots, attract, pull off, extricate, get out, shoot, tire, arouse; s'en --, get oneself out, manage, get along; -- au sort à qui ..., draw lots to see who....
titre, _m._ title, claim, right; à -- de, by virtue of being.
pr._ (familiar), you, to you (occasionally: thou, thee, to thee); à --, your turn.
toiser, _v._ to size up, measure, eye from head to toot.
tolérer, _v._ to tolerate; -- que, bear to have.
tombeki, _m._ kind of tobacco raised chiefly in Persia (usually written tombéki).
tomber, _v._ to fall, fall down, drop; faire --, make fall, empty (ashes, etc.); le jour tombe, it grows dark; à la nuit tombante, au jour tombant, at nightfall.
Tombouctou, Timbuktu (African town on the upper Niger).
Tonkin, _m._ Tonkin (French protectorate in Indo-China, definitively conquered in 1885).
toque, _f._ Hat cap, toque (the French judge's toque suggests a cylinder flaring at the top).
tordre, _v._ to twist, wring; se --, writhe, laugh convulsively.
tort, _m._ wrong, harm, stigma; avoir --, to be wrong; à --, wrongly.
torture, _f._ torture, torment; mettre l'esprit à la --, to rack one's brains.
toucher, _v._ to touch, touch on; -- à, touch, meddle with, border on, draw near; touchant,-e, touching, pathetic.
toujours, _adv._ always, all the time, continuously, ever, still, nevertheless, at any rate.
tour, _m._ turn, circuit, trip around, trick, feat; faire le -- (de), to make the circuit, fun around; -- à --, in turn.
tourelle, _f._ turret; escalier en --, winding turret stairway.

tourner, _v._ to turn, flank, turn around or over or the corner of, turn out, wind, twist, bend, circle; se --, turn oneself, turn, turn around; mal --, take a turn for the worse, turn out badly; mal tourné, badly formed or built, homely; -- au plafond, encircle the ceiling.

and s._ all, every, everything, everyone, wholly, quite, very, wide (open), any; --le jour, all day; tous les jours, every day; en -- cas, in any case; -- à fait, wholly, entirely, altogether, wholeheartedly; -- de même, all the same; pas du --, not at all; rien du --, nothing at all; -- au plus, at the very most; c'est -- au plus si je pourrais, at the very most I could only; avoir de --, to have something of everything; -- un jour, an entire day; comme --, as everything, as anything; toute fée que je sois, fairy though I be; -- en, while, all the time (with participle); le --, all (when tous stands alone, without a noun, _s_ is pronounced).
Tramasset (Édouard), Coppée's cousin, to whom he dedicated _Le Louis d'Or_.
train, _m._ pace, rate, bustle, course, train, raft, train of boats; en -- de, in the act of, about to; -- de bateaux, line of boats, tow.
trainer, _v._ to drag, draw, drawl; se --, drag oneself along.
trait, _m._ trace, shaft, trait, feature, draught.
traiter, _v._ to treat, treat of; -- de, treat as, call.
trancher, _v._ to cut, cut off or out, stand out, form a contrast; tranchant, -e, adj.
tranquille, _adj._ tranquil, quiet; laisser --, to let alone, let be; vivre --, live quietly (_ll_ in this and the next three words is not liquid).
tranquilliser, _v._ to tranquilize, quiet, make easy.
travail, _m._ work, labor, laboring; instrument de --, tool.
travailler, _v._ to work, till, plow through, torment; travaillé, -e, worked, wrought.
travers, _m._ breadth, width; à --, through, across; au -- de, through; en --, crosswise; en -- de, across, through; de --, awry, not on straight, crooked, crosswise, sidewise, askance, wrong.
traverser, _v._ to cross, pass through, traverse.
trembler, _v._ to tremble; tremblant, -e, trembling, quaking, shaking.
trinquer, _v._ to touch glasses before drinkingo triolet, _m._ triolet, triplet.
troisième, _ord._ third; chambre du --, fourth-story room.
tromper, _v._ to deceive, disappoint; se --, be mistaken, make a mistake.
trop, _adv._ too, too much; pas --, not too much, not very much.
trouble, _m._ trouble, embarrassment, confusion, disturbance, distress.
troubler, _v._ to trouble, disturb, confuse, excite; se --, be disturbed, become troubled.
trouer, _v._ to make a hole in, pierce; troué, -e, pierced, full of holes.
troupe, _f._ troop, crowd, brood (of chickens), litter (of pigs); de la --, soldiers.
trousse, _f._ case; aux trousses (de), at one's heels.
trouver, _v._ to find, consider, discover, hit on; se --, find oneself, be found, chance to be, be, find that one has, offer an opportunity; s'en -- bien, find it good for one.
truisse, _f._ clump of trees (used especially in La Vendée).
turban, _m._ turban; valeurs à --, Turkish stocks (financial vernacular).
and s._ Turkish, Turk (written Turc when _s._).
turco, _m._ turco (Algerian soldier in the French service).
U uhlan, _m._ uhlan (German lancer; no elision before this word).
art._ one, a, an; l'--, one; les uns ...
others; les uns les autres, one another; les uns aux autres, to one another; l'-- et l'autre, both; se regarder l'-- l'autre, to look at each other.
user, _v._ to use up, wear out, use, -- de, make use of.
vaciller, _v._ to vacillate, reel, totter, shake.
valet, _m._ valet, man-servant, farm-hand; -- de chambre, man-servant.
valoir, _v._ to be worth; -- mieux, be worth more, be better.
Van den Berg, name of the Doyen in _la Montre du Doyen_ (_van_ is the Dutch prefix corresponding to the German _von, Berg_ = mountain, in German).
vanter, _v._ to boast of, brag about, extol.
vapeur, _f._ vapor, steam, fume, mist; _m._ steamer.
vaquer, _v._ to be vacant; -- à, attend to, go about.
veiller, _v._ to watch, sit up; -- à, watch over; veille sur toi, look out for yourself.
vendetta, _f._ vendetta, blood-feud (in Italian, = vengeance; _en_ pronounced as in _bien_).
vendre, _v._ to sell; à --, for sale.
vénération, _f._ veneration; avoir en --, to worship.
venir, _v._ to come; -- de, come from, have just; -- à, come to, happen; s'en --, come away or along; venu, _m._ comer.
vent, _m._ wind; au --, in the wind, flying.
Vénus, Venus; cheveux de --, kind of maidenhair fern.
venvole (à la), _adv._ heedlessly, lightly (obsolescent; formerly and incorrectly written vanvole, the word is derived from vent).
verdir, _v._ to make or turn green.
verre, _m._ glass; petit --, small glass of brandy.
verser, _v._ to pour, pour forth or out, shed.
verset, _m._ verse (of a hymn, of the Koran, etc.).
verste, _f._ verst (Russian measure, about one kilometer).
vêtement, _m._ garment, piece of clothing; _pl._ clothes.
viager, -gère, _adj._ for life; rente viagère, life annuity.
vibrer, _v._ to vibrate, quiver; vibrant, -e, vibrating, resounding, quivering, tremulous.
vider, _v._ to empty; se --, be emptied, empty oneself.
and adj._ virgin; la sainte Vierge, the Holy Virgin.
and s._ old, old man or woman.
vif, vive, _adj._ lively, alive, keen, brisk, bright, vivid, living.
vignette, _f._ vignette (small ornamental engraving in a book, on letter-paper, etc.).
vilain, -e, _adj._ mean, dirty, nasty, coarse, wretched, ugly, scandalous.
villa, _f._ villa (in this and in the next four words _ll_ is not liquid).
Villemomble, village 8 miles east of Paris.
vin, _m._ wine; -- du Rhin, Rhine wine.
vivement, _adv._ quickly, briskly, heartily, intensely, keenly.
vivre, _v._ to live, be alive; pour --, live, live on; vive!; long live!; vivant, -e, living, alive.
voici, _prep._ here is, here are, ago, you see here, etc.; le --, here he (it) is.
voie, _f._ way; en bonne --, on the road to recovery.

Ypsilanti (Alexandre), Alexander Ypsilanti (or Hypsilanti), a Greek who became an officer in the Russian army; in 1820 he became the head of the Greek Hetreria, a secret society founded in Odessa for the purpose of liberating Greece from the Turks, and in 1821 he led an insurrection against the Turks in the Danube provinces and inaugurated the Greek war for independence; after a number of mistakes (_cf.
the déroute de Skouliani_) and humiliating defeats, and after having been dismissed from the Russian army, he died in poverty (1792-1828).
